Arbuthnot today announces its intention to sell approximately 5.8 million ordinary shares of 40 pence each in Secure Trust (the "Sale Shares"), such amount to potentially increase subject to additional demand being secured, representing approximately 31.9 per cent. of Secure Trust's existing issued share capital, by way of a secondary placing to institutional investors only (the "Sale"). The Sale is expected to be priced at £25 per Sale Share (the "Sale Shares Price") which represents a 10.7 per cent. discount to the closing price of Secure Trust's ordinary shares (the "Ordinary Shares") as of 26 May 2016.

PM

£145m proceeds

BE

Here's Shore to put some context on things.

11:17 am
BE

Arbuthnot Bank^ (ARBB, NR CNP, 1,489p) has announced that it plans to sell 5.8 million shares in Secure Trust Bank (31.9% of the issued share capital) at a price of 2,500p per share (being a 10.7% discount to yesterday’s closing price). This will result in Arbuthnot‘s stake in Secure Trust Bank reducing from 51.9% (a consolidated position) to approximately 20.0% (an associate interest) thereby resulting in it ceding control of the group. Following the share sale, Secure Trust Bank will seek to move its listing from AIM to a Premium Listing on the Main Market. In addition, Sir Henry Angest plans to relinquish his role as Chairman of Secure Trust Bank, with a new non-executive replacement to be announced alongside the Main Market listing. Finally, we note that the 165p special dividend that was proposed by Secure Trust Bank at the time of the full year results announcement in March will not be formally declared until after the sale process is complete, thus meaning that the right to receive this payment will be transferred to the new shareholders.

We view this move as a significant fundamental step in the development of Secure Trust Bank. The sale of shares by Arbuthnot Bank and the proposed move to a Main Market listing will significantly improve their liquidity, in our view, thereby enhancing the stock’s appeal to a broader range of potential investors. Furthermore, we think this could be a precursor to more significant strategic action by the group, which could ultimately see it accelerating its growth trajectory and entering new markets, possibly by way of a substantial acquisition. Although the company is extremely well capitalised following the recent sale of Everyday Loans to Non-Standard Finance^ (NSF, NR CP, 69.75p), a sizeable acquisition may require further equity issuance. Any potential new investors should therefore be aware that a further cash call could be possible.

Based on our current forecasts, which remain unchanged, Secure Trust Bank is trading on a y/e December 2016F PER of 18.6x,dividend yield of 2.7% (excluding the special which yields an additional 5.9%) and P/TNAV of 2.2x for an ROTE of 15.2%. We view Secure Trust as a high quality specialist lender with a strong and clearly ambitious management team. That said, current valuation metrics are relatively full when compared to quoted specialist banking peers and, while it is a company that we hold in high regard, we currently see more attractive investment opportunities elsewhere in the sector, noting our positive stances on OneSavings Bank^ (OSB, Buy at 322p), Paragon Group^ (PAG, Buy at 311p) and Shawbrook Group^ (Buy at 299p). Therefore we retain a neutral stance on Secure Trust Bank and expect the shares to trade down towards the 2,500p placing price this morning. HOLD

PM

(jimpj -- yes, Erika's a great correspondent)

11:37 am
BE

Anyway, today's M&S sellers are Stifel and I think SocGen.

BE

Stifel first.

BE

Any recovery plan that details short-term pain without putting numbers on the longer-term gain will struggle to
support an optimistic share price. Longer-term profit targets could only realistically have been predicated on
stronger sales, and it would be a bold/foolish management team that would be prepared to predict the timing
of any sales improvement. Hence visibility will remain low for some time. This is not the reason for our
downgrade, though. Instead we’re not convinced that customers will respond to the changes planned, thereby
limiting the chances of a sales and profit recovery and bringing further downside risk. So while the shares
continue to look cheap on a free cash flow basis, we downgrade to Hold from Buy.

11:38 am
BE

Management is making significant changes to the clothing offer, taking prices
down by an average 15% on 30% of the range, simplifying the range and its
merchandising and giving greater emphasis to Good categories at the
expense of Better and Best.

BE

Alongside price investments, there will be additional significant changes,
addressing customer frustrations, improving availability and making the
clothing offer easier to shop. Specifically, a better balance of style versus
fashion, merchandising (and purchasing) more by category than by sub-brand
(40% co-ordinated vs. 70% previously) and editing the currently
“overwhelming” choice, with SKUs down c.10%, 9 phases vs. 14 and 4 sales
periods vs. 9.

BE

What’s good about it?
It addresses customer (and non customer) feedback and reverses a strategy
focused on seeking to drive sales in the higher-ASP more fashion-driven
Better and Best sub brands.

11:39 am
BE

What are our concerns?
As much as it might be the case that the ASP-driven strategy didn’t work
(evidenced by declining sales), it replaced a price and volume-driven “Good”
focused strategy which worked to some degree in stronger market conditions
but stumbled in the recession and, in our view, is not as relevant in today's
clothing market.
We think there is a high risk that there is a sizeable gap between what
customers tell M&S they want (keener pricing on core products, less
complication in product ranges and instore-merchandising) and their actual
buying response to such changes. However analytical and data-driven
management’s decisions now are, market trends suggest that core
“need-driven” clothing purchases are under pressure and the most successful
retailers are those generating strong “want-driven” demand for their more
fashion-led items.

BE

Other risks


That price investments are simply the “pay to play” price of defending market share or stemming sales declines, rather than growth-driving, and hence might be perpetual rather than a one-off reset.
That it will take longer to wean customers off the promotional and markdown drugs than
anticipated, with these drags offsetting any improvement in core full-price sales. Having been told for many periods that reduced promotional spend was one of the main drivers of sales weakness, management disclosed that promotional participation has been steadily rising and stood at 40% of sales last year. Hence, there is further to go with the sales drag from unwinding promotional participation than we had understood.

BE

.... and I can't currently find SocGen, so you'll have to trust me that it says basically the same.

Satellite services company SES SA Thursday said it planned to acquire the 49.5% in O3b Networks Ltd. it doesn’t already own for $710 million and would issue shares to fund the transaction.

The move deepens Luxembourg-based SES’s bet on the market for beaming high-speed Internet to remote locations.

SES moved to buy all of O3b less than a month ago, paying $20 million to take a controlling stake in the startup by raising its 49.1% investment to 50.5%. It retained a call option to buy the rest which it now is exercising.

11:43 am
PM

Industry competitor SES announced last night that it is to take full ownership of O3b, a Ka band operator of medium earth orbit satellites, at a total enterprise valuation of $2.6bn. This valuation excludes the future capex of c$600m necessary to complete the build out of its fleet. The read-across for Avanti is highly positive.

PM

Full ownership. SES announced last night a €1bn capital raise to fund the $710m move to 100% ownership of O3b Networks. O3b revenue for the year to Dec 2015 was $56m.

O3b Valuation. The headline valuation represents a multiple of 46x 2015 revenues. Guidance in the prospectus suggests O3b is expected to grow its revenues to $100m in 2016E (+78% yoy) which equates to a 26x 2016E sales multiple.

Disruption. After a spate of profit warnings from the mature operators, due in part to the disruptive impact of the new HTS entrants, this benchmark highlights the value that the industry places on the newer Ka band satellite operators. Avanti has established a leading position as the only pure play listed HTS operator in EMEA and has valuable spectrum rights covering Europe, the Middle East and most of the Americas.

Read-across. Avanti's enterprise value of c$688m equates to an EV/sales multiple of less than 7x June 2016E revenues. This contrasts sharply with the headline valuation for O3b. We believe O3b fleet is not fully financed and has a very material capex cycle ahead of it. With the expected launches of Hylas 3 and 4 next year, Avanti's fleet is fully funded and we expect the group to become free cash flow positive shortly thereafter.

BT/EE. Furthermore, Avanti has recently announced major prestige contract wins, including a 4G backhaul deal with EE. We estimate that Avanti’s addressable market is larger than that of O3b due to its simpler and more flexible technology platform.

PM

PM

Let me share some Jefferies as well

PM

Key Takeaway
We never doubted SES's appetite to own 100% of O3b, but we are left scratching our head as to why it's made the move now given the financial logic of waiting and the protections afforded by the options. The upcoming CMD will be critical in answering why issuing equity into the maelstrom of a vociferous debate around data price deflation was a good idea. Given the shares trade well below fair value (in our view), we'd expect the placing discount to be small.

11:46 am
BE

Hm.

PM

Why now (SES's view): In the release SES has gone to great lengths to expound on why it has decided to make the move to 100% now (and we discuss below why we think it could / should have waited) - it has reiterated all previous rhetoric around the strategic logic - it has also reiterated all previous financial guidance for O3b ($1.2bn of net debt to be consolidated, $32-36m revenue per satellite, $100m of 2016 revenue and backlog of $350m). The one area of upside is that with the early repayment of O3b's most expensive debt, FCF and net income accretion is now expected in 2018 (previously net income accretion was guided to be in 2018/19).

Why now (Jefferies view): The timing of the move to 100% ownership of O3b surprises us - we never doubted that the strategic intent was complete control, but our base case would have been that SES used the protection of the call option and the lack of appeal of an O3b IPO for the minority shareholders as sufficient comfort to hold off on moving to 100% control for a couple of years, in which time O3b could grow its EBITDA such that the leverage impact of 100% consolidation could be absorbed within the 3.3x leverage threshold and therefore avoid any equity raise. As it is, SES will now be issuing equity at a two year low in the midst of a vociferous industry debate around fixed data price deflation. Some may even be questioning that such a seemingly illogical move could presage further bad news. The message from the company is that the move to 100% control (and the commercial and financial synergies that comes with it) justifies the move. This could well be true - and the upcoming CMD on 21 June gives management the stage upon which to articulate this story. In the meantime, the market is likely to be worryingly scratching its head.

PM

TheLeggie -- you can have more than a wink. You can have Chris Silva in person at Camp AV

11:47 am
PM

He's not in the schedule yet, but he's coming along for a chat

BE

Hm. Personally, I'm amazed -- amazed -- that SES got the cash call away.

BE

The word overnight was that the fundraising was going badly, and there appear to be valid and unanswered questions about satellite market structure at the moment.

11:48 am
BE

As we've spoken about a lot with reference to Inmarsat, which has a lot of bandwidth and no customers.

BE

Barclays sees sense in it all, though.

BE

The logic of combining O3b and SES is clear. Following Eutelsat’s recent warning, it is clear that structural changes are unfolding right now in some parts of the Satellite Data market. O3b’s High Throughput Satellite capacity allows SES to go to market with a combination of traditional widebeam capacity and focused beams offering a much “bigger pipe” for some specific applications, such as trunking, cruise ship connectivity and government. It remains to be seen whether this approach can mean that ultimately SES escapes some impact from lower pricing in Data, for which new HTS capacity seems to be a catalyst (as seen by Eutelsat).

11:48 am
BE

However, SES could have been combining its offerings with O3b without moving to 100% of the equity. Why launch a placing now? SES has a call option that it can exercise at any time on the 49.5% of O3b that it does not own, allowing that portion to be purchased for $710m. The other O3b shareholders then have a put option (effective from 1 October 2017) to force SES to purchase those same remaining shares for the same amount of $710m. In our note from 4 May, we estimated that SES’s net debt/EBITDA would move to c.3.5x at end-2017 if it were to take out the rest of O3b for cash. Management has always stated that the ceiling for the company's credit rating and the level management is comfortable with is 3.3x.

The other benefit is a financial synergy. At a 50.5% holding, SES had the right to refinance 25% of O3b’s c.$1.2bn debt, upon which it is paying a blended rate of 9.5%. At a 100% holding, it has the right to refinance the whole debt. We show a scenario below for how much that could save.

So there is a real benefit here, but it is a still a surprise to us that management should launch a capital raising to move to 100% so soon after going above 50%.

BE

I'm struggling to see any of this this as positive for an industry that's structurally deep in flux. Whatever, though.

PM

( fjp73 -- we have two ex-con this year, neither on the schedule yet. One is world famous, the other is called Steve Dagworthy...)
